title: 107_s606
content: The "Ombudsman Reauthorization Act of 2002" is cited as the official title. Section 2008 of the Solid Waste Disposal Act is amended to establish the Office of Ombudsman. The Ombudsman Reauthorization Act of 2002 establishes the Office of the Ombudsman within the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA). The Office is an independent entity with a defined structure. The Office of the Ombudsman within the EPA must adhere to professional guidelines and be headed by an Ombudsman appointed by the President with Senate approval. The Ombudsman must have prior experience in a government ombudsman role and cannot have been an employee of the EPA. The Ombudsman appointed for the EPA must not have been an Agency employee in the year before appointment. The term is 5 years, renewable once. The President can only remove the Ombudsman for neglect of duty or malfeasance, with reasons communicated to Congress. The Ombudsman's duties include receiving complaints, providing assistance, conducting investigations, making findings, and giving nonbinding recommendations to the Administrator regarding various programs and requirements under different Acts. The Ombudsman appointed for the EPA has the power to investigate Agency actions, select matters for action, prescribe complaint methods, determine investigation scope, request action notifications from the Administrator. The Ombudsman appointed for the EPA has the authority to request assistance and information from Federal agencies, examine records and properties under their jurisdiction, issue subpoenas for testimony and evidence. The Ombudsman appointed for the EPA has the authority to request assistance and information from Federal agencies, examine records and properties under their jurisdiction, issue subpoenas for testimony and evidence. Additionally, the Ombudsman may produce documentary evidence, seek enforcement of subpoenas in court, participate in conferences or inquiries, administer oaths, and hold hearings related to investigations conducted by the Office. The Ombudsman appointed for the EPA has the authority to engage in alternative dispute resolution, communicate with various parties, and administer the Office's budget. The Ombudsman is also responsible for appointing Deputy Ombudsmen for each region, hiring necessary assistants and employees, and supervising personnel. The Ombudsman appointed for the EPA has the authority to supervise, evaluate, and take personnel actions with employees of the Office. The Ombudsman can delegate responsibilities to other employees except for issuing subpoenas and making recommendations to the Administrator. Additionally, the Ombudsman must maintain contact information in each region separate from the regional office of the Agency. The Ombudsman for the EPA has reporting duties, including publishing an annual report on health and environmental concerns, issuing reports on investigations, and soliciting comments from the Agency. Investigations conducted by the Ombudsman constitute legal matters under specific sections of the United States Code. Employee protection is ensured, prohibiting employers from retaliating against employees who comply with the Ombudsman's provisions. Employees who feel they have been discharged or discriminated against for complying with the Ombudsman's provisions can file a complaint within 180 days. This section does not limit any remedy or right of appeal and can be carried out regardless of any contrary laws. The establishment of the Office of the Ombudsman does not impact procedures for grievances, appeals, or administrative matters. Authorization of appropriations includes $3,000,000 for fiscal years 2003 and 2004, $4,000,000 for fiscal years 2005 through 2008, and $5,000,000 for fiscal years 2009 through 2012. The President must include a separate line item for the Office's funding in the annual budget to Congress. Passed the Senate on November 20, 2002. Signed by JERI THOMSON, Secretary.
